text: appearance: very dark cola brown, dark purplish highlights, fulsome tan head.  aroma: 	big nose full of candi sugar, molasses, plum, raisin, cherry, leather, pipe tobacco, and earth. taste: sweet candi sugar, brown sugar, plum, fig, clove, brown bread, yeast, toffee, and wood. finish: 	smooth sweetness lasts, balanced by just a bit of drying yeasty notes. notes: 	Really nice quad. Best by 1/23/2017, aged for a few years. No real oxidation detected, but everything felt extremely smooth. No harshness of booze, just slow warmth. Tasty.  Bottle from the Rare Beer Club.
Its a big fruity boozy beer, just like youd expect for the style. Its perhaps a touch on the sweet side compared to some of the more traditional examples.

Best before December 6th 2017

A small pop when I pulled the cork out, it pours a clear reddish brown with a finger of off white foam. Lacing is impressive


Loads of caramel malt in the smell with some dark pitted fruit thats on the subtle side. The sweet seems likely to be influenced by candi sugar, I reckon.

Tastes of caramel malt and probably a bit of oxidation. Dark fruits are a mild presence. Candi sugar here but doesnt cause any over sweetness. Alcohol is definitely there and brings oodles of warming.

Close to a syrupy mouthfeel, I really do like this Quad.
Bottle from rotter. About 5 years old.  Moderate oxidized nose, mostly cardboard. Moderate dried dark fruits. Taste is similar with a moderate cherry component.

750ml bottle to snifter pours a medium mahogany color with slight head and little lacing. the aroma is bready yeast, some dark fruits, Belgian candy and sugars, sweet malts and a very mild alcohol touch. the flavors are melded together nicely. upfront is the Belgian candy and sugars, quite sweet and sweeter than I think It should be. Bready yeast followed on the end by a mild warming alcohol. I would give this a higher score if it wasnt so sweet...its not bad buts its noticeable. still get some dark fruit action in there...fig or plum but probably plum...overall very tasty and I would search out another. the date on the bottle is 12/23/14 I dont know if that is the born on date or the drink by date. salut

From the 750 ml. corked caged bottle with an expiration date of 12/6/2017. Lovely mahogany[-reddish hued pour under a long lasting silky tan head. Big Belgian candied sugar, coriander, and roasted malt notes on the nose. No booze. The body is medium to full. The taste is far more sweet than I would have liked with a doughy-breadiness in there too. But it ends with an accentuated bitter bite. Yes, I would drink it again.
bottle poured into a snifter..burgundy with a fluffy off white head..aroma of dark fruits,toffee,bread..tastes of raisins,plums,figs,toffee..good stuff
750ml bottle pours a dark brown color with a bit of a head. Caramel mild sweetness and some plum.

Dark amber / light brown, tan head, moderate coarseness, 3mm fades to frothy film. Aroma is raisins with a touch of happy sappy everygreen and a hint of grapefruit. moderate caramel. grass. Slight pondwater. Aroma is much more fresh than a Trappist (such as the La Trappe Quad that I just had). Body is medium-heavy, moderately syrupy, slightly gritty, moderate-to-moderate-strong carbonation, medium-heavy burn, medium-fine coarseness. Flavor is sweet raisin, some strawberry, prune, fresh grass and herbal weeds/brush, fairly spicy/phenolic (although not as much as some American Belgians.) Overall, a decent American attempt at a quad. It does taste fairly green and has some spiciness that again fails to mask its American origin. Nothing that special. The sweetness actually gets a bit cloying.
Very enjoyable. Hazy brown pour with thick off white head. Aroma is ready and yeasty. Taste follows as a sweet version of the nose.

Bottle acquired in 2013, stamped best before 2017. I drank the same batch about a year ago, and I think it is as good or a little better. Aroma is great, burnt caramel, roasty, dark, boozy. Heavy and sweet, but a bright, fruity sweetness. More caramel, rum, raisins. Its a little more fizzy feeling than Id like for the flavors, but thats about as critical as I can get.

2010 Bomber - Dark tea colored pour with plenty of head but no retention. Nose is a bomb of dark fruit, figs, dates, and bread. Taste is super smooth with lots of dark fruit as well. A few years has done well for this bottle. One of the better Abt Quads I have had especially from this side of the Atlantic.  Well hidden alcohol and a good kick of sweetness.
Sample at the Beer Heads MeetUp bottle share event in October 2014. Pours a hazy light cola brown with an ecru head. Caramel nose. Flavors of butterscotch. Smooth finish. Nice quad.

750 ml bottle poured into a La Trappe chalice. Pours a clear dark brown with a thin velvety head of beige foam. The aroma is a little alcoholic for my liking,but there is some nice ester notes of clove and a bit of anise. The ttaste is softly sweet with some alcohol heat on the back end. Velvety mouthfeel. Moderate carbonation.

750 mL bottle. (2011 vintage.) Hazy copper-brown with a nice, almost-white head. Yeast, bready malt, booze, candi sugar in the nose. Nice, but not particularly distinctive. Yeast, dried fruit, booze, and a nice earthiness in the flavour. A touch of herbs and brown spice. Not too sweet. Booze isnt hot. quite tasty.

Pretty good. It had an aroma of bready malts, burnt sugar and spice. Lighter brown and amber color with a thin head. Lighter palate than most quads with moderate carbonation. Heavy malt flavors followed by burnt sugar with spicy yeast and a tinge of coffee. It blended well and went down easy.

750 mL bottle from Total Wine, Raleigh, NC (Triangle). Brownish-orange pour with a frothy off-white head. Aroma of grape, raisin, beet sugars, and sweet plums. Taste is a well-balanced blend of dark fruit, caramel, candi sugars, and Belgian yeast. Moderate alcohol warming but most of it is well-hidden. A very nice interpretation of a quad.
Wonderful example of style! Sweet and flavorful aroma and taste which is truly Belgium. Alcohol well hidden.

750 ml bottle into chalice, best before 1/23/2017. Pours lightly cloudy pale ruby red color with a 1 finger fairly dense off white head with good retention, that reduces to a thin cap that lingers. Spotty soapy lacing clings on the glass, with a good amount of streaming carbonation. Aromas of big raisin, plum, fig, cherry, apricot, pear, apple, caramel, toast, brown bread, candi sugar, pepper, light clove, herbal, and yeast earthiness. Damn nice aromas with good balance and complexity of fruity/earthy yeast and dark/bready malt notes; with great strength. Taste of big raisin, plum, cherry, fig, apricot, apple, caramel, toast, brown bread, candi sugar, pepper, light clove, herbal, and yeast earthiness. Lingering notes of raisin, plum, cherry, fig, apricot, apple, toast, brown bread, candi sugar, pepper, light clove, herbal, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a while. Fantastic complexity and balance of fruity/earthy yeast and dark/bready malt flavors; with a great malt/fruity/spicy flavor balance and zero cloying sweetness after the finish. Medium carbonation and medium-full bodied; with a very smooth, lightly slick/bready, and fairly crisp mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is very well hidden with only a light warming present after the finish. Overall this is an awesome quadruple style. All around great complexity and balance of fruity/earthy yeast and dark/bready malt flavors; and very smooth and crisp to sip on for the ABV. A highly enjoyable offering.

750ml bottle, thanks to DanielCoor for sharing. Bottle #3067, date is 1/24/12. ABV labeled 9.9%. Hazy burnt orange amber color. Thin off-white head. Lots of bits in the body. Bigger body, sort of slick. Very sharp carbonation, and soft. Caramel malt, dark fruit, some prune. Lightly spicy. Moderate sweet taste, moderate bitter. Lightly peppery. Solid quad. Friends seemed to like it quite a bit. Gets better as it goes.. Great dark malty, almost milk chocolatey aroma. Great dark fruit notes to it. Kind of vinous. Man... Gets much better as it goes and sits. Soft, sharp carbonation turns into creamy and mellow. Very nice.

Refrigerated 75 cl brown bottle corked and capped poured into a Trappist glass. Pours translucent mahogany with off-white head which dissipates quickly. Aroma is some dark fruit, medium body, medium carbonation, and very little lacing. Taste is caramel, dark fruit (mostly fig and some raisin), dark candy sugar, and some alcohol.

Bottle to glass. Pours a nutty brown with a slight red hue. Tan head that fades quickly leaving no head. My first thought was beer might be flat but beeer is lively on the palate. Aroma is sweet with some spice. Taste is what you would expect from a quad. Dark fruits, toffee, brown sugar. Very fizzy on the tongue. The taste is very good but there is something off and I cant put my finger on it.

750 ml bottle: clear mahagony pour with an off-white head. Aroma of dates, figs, grapes, spice with hints of chocolate. Sweet caramelized flavor of dates, raisins and figs. Hints of chocolate and alcohol. Tasty beer.

Poured from a 750ml bottle, shared with my wife on Christmas eve. The aroma is fruity alcohol sweetness, dark stone fruits, melanoidin rich maltiness, big yeast character. The flavor is similar to the aroma, there is a nice sweetness that cuts through in the finish, hints of spice. This is a damn fine beer. Perfect for this cold night.
Draught at World of Beers, Key West. Dark brown colour with an off-white head. Aroma and flavour of spice, dreid fruit, nuts, yeast, malt and alcohol.

I had this at Global Brew. Pours reddish-brown with a tan head. Taste sweet, Carmel, dark fruit. I thought this was pretty good. I would definitely drink this again.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A: Dark Brown Hue, Passes Little Light, Off White Head Ring, Some Lacing

S: Light Dark Skinned Fruits, Mildly Funky, Mild Chocolate

T: Sweet Plums, Tart Cherries, Milk Chocolate

M: Decent Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Mildly Sweet

Overall, a decent Quad with some mildly fruity overtones.
Dark fruit sweetness on nose, more dark fruit and spices on palate. Nice sweetness but not cloying. Really tasty

Lovely clear brown body with an off-white fizzy head. Appealing aroma of grapes, chocolate, nuts, ... Moderately bitter, heavily sweet flavour. Very complex mouthfeel of dark fruit and chocolate. Very enjoyable.
Bottle with Pedro. Pours a cloud amber with medium beige head and some soapy lace. Nose of figs, prunes, raisin, spiced rum. Medium to full body with a sticky palate. Smooth for the abv.

Bottle from a beer club. Pours a dark reddish amber color with a moderate off-white head on it. Nose is a little toasty up front, but yields quickly to some sweeter and dark fruit notes. Taste is definitely a little sweet with the same dark fruitiness, but with a long-lasting sweetness that seems a bit muddled to me.
750 ml. bottle. Pours reddish brown with a nice biege head. Aroma of fruit, malt, caramel, and spice. Taste is dark fruit, malt, spice, caramel, and a bit of alcohol. Well made.

Dark amber/cider color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of sweet malt, yeast, dark fruit, some caramel, & rich spice; Flavor of sweet malt, yeast, dark fruit (notably prunes & dates), caramel, and raisons; Warm finish; Nicely balanced; Good overall, but would like to try again with some more aging.

750ml to glass. Pours light brown/golden color, clear with a good fluffy white head. Bread, carmel, plums come thru on the aroma. Taste is sweet, carmel, butterscotch, bitter, and a hint of tobacco. Warms the palate and the belly. Good Quad, but would rather have others that are mass produced.

The Abbot 12 won a Gold Medal at the 2005 Great American Beer Festival and is described by the brewery as: "A strong, dark ale with notes of raisins, figs, and caramel, and a pronounced dark rum character. Deceptively smooth at 10.5% alcohol, this strong ale is ideal as an after-dinner sipping brew."

This bottle listed a 9.9% abv with an original gravity of 22.5 plato, and poured out with a generous lingering tan head. The dark aged fruit aromas wafted up and brought to mind rich brown malts, mixing with some background yeast spiciness. The flavor was candi-sugar sweet, with the slightest hint of cocoa/dark chocolate, a little alcohol as it warmed brought to mind rum, sweetly blanketing the mouth with its rich, thick body. This beer reminds me of Westvleteren, and thats not a comparison made often, if at all.

This beer is the perfect accompaniment to a crisp, cool fall evening, sipped slowly along with a snack of nutty, sharp, aged Holland gouda. I think that Im going to need a case of this beer to survive the coming winter.

750mL bottle, sent from BrewtopiaofPJ (thanks Mark), pours a deep dark mahogany / amber with a large off-white / beige head. Aroma of Belgian spices, toffee, some floral notes and candied sugar. Flavour is very complex and luscious, full of floral notes, caramel, some light spices, and candied sugar. Extremely complex flavour, with a wonderful integration of the different flavours - the sweetness is perfectly situated, never becoming cloying. Not as elegant as something like Rochefort 10 or St. Bernardus 12, but certainly one of the best American quads. Excellent.

Best before January 24, 2017.
Appearance: This is a beautiful quad, from deep garnet hue that is absolutely crystal clear to the thin but dense light tan head that settles into a dense coating. This wants to be drank.
Aroma: The aroma is unfortunately mild, but theres a deep fruitiness to it that hints at fig, grape and medicinal cherries on the pour that yields to a spicy dough aroma. I wish the aroma were stronger as its great.
Taste: The flavor takes the aroma and amplifies it in strength, giving this a deep fruit flavor backed by light spices. The fruit flavors hint at syrupy grape and cherry along with a hint of figs that intertwine from start to finish over top of a doughy body that finishes spicy. Boy this sips nice.
Palate: Thick and slightly syrupy with light carbonation that has a slightly sharp edge to it.
Overall: This is an excellent quad, I will not be passing up this brewerys beer anymore. I highly recommend buying this if you see it, though I wonder if this would really hold up to a few years of age. I think this is ready to go now.

Bottle on the balcony with the wife. Aroma of raisins, sherry, brown sugar, booze. Full bodied, but with decent carbonation. Flavors of plum, dried fruit, brown sugar. Long finish, with red ripe berried and more dried fruit developing. Exquisite.
Mahogany, off-white head. Nose is rum raisin, port, big booze. Taste is late vintage port, raisins, chocolate, brown sugar, prunes. Very boozy and warming. Smooth light mouthfeel.

This thing is killer! and i dont like quads.... Sample pour of deep dark burnt caramel with tan head.  Nose comes through with plenty of caramel and smooth malts, not too much sweet or dried fruit, thank goodness!  Flavor is the same, again, smooth caramel malt and a mild spice with a mild sweet dried fruit, but not too much.  This thing is great!

Pours deep dark brown with a fizzy off-white head that dissipates quickly. Dark fruits, some caramel, raisins, baking spices, and just a touch of grape, which I actually really like. Nice, full body, but good and clean. This is really quite good -- up there with the Roche for me.

Did anyone else have a really hard time getting the cork out? Anyway, this is a powerful abbey ale with intense flavor. Carmel notes and raisin. Great dark red color. Nice weight in the palate and the alcohol, although not exceedingly high, is well hidden. Great selection. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

(Bottle). Deep brown-amber complexion with long head retention. Flavors of prune, sherry, sweet malt and mild spice. Alcohol nicely concealed. Excellent Belgian-style American Quad. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Garnet color, decent head retention and lacing, bitter and sweet notes of raisin fig sherry, nice beer

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a clear dark garnet with a lasting, though thin, light tan head.  Aroma is dark dried fruit.  Taste is sweet caramel malt, but short of cloying, along with the dark fruit again.  Theres also a butteriness to the taste that connects the initial sweetness with the following tartness.  This is a great brew.

Pours a dark chestnut brown color with a soapy off-white head.  Aroma of dark fruit, fig, Belgian yeast, and hint of alcohol.  Sweet flavor with dark fruit, fig, and caramel with a hint of Belgian yeast and alcohol warmth.

Surprisingly mild aroma with cookie dough, yeast, and alcohol.  Flavor is candy-sweet, with bread, caramel, brown sugar, and apple.  A little bitterness and some drying alcohol in the finish.  If youre in the mood for a treat, this beer is worth seeking out.
Belgian Brew Fest. Very good clone of classic Trappist beers.  I found the sweetness to be a bit on the high side though.

Bottle.  Pours dark brown with ruby highlights and thin, fizzy off-white head; short retention and minimal lacing.  Aroma is booze, bread and cookie malts, caramel, figs, dates, and floral hops.  Flavor is sweet malt forward with supporting dark fruit esters and light hops; booze undertones throughout with a dry finish.  Medium/full body and low carbonation.

New Beer Distributors, NY 750ml ($7.50): I think I got a weird bottle. I opened it and all the carbonation was gone. Everything else about the beer seems to be fine. Perhaps the bottle is just rather old... if carbonation dissipates with age. Well, whatever, I dont know. Anyway, MY pour was a murky light brown with barely any  head. Aroma is complex, dark fruits, booze, cake, and some other fancy stuff. Although this beer may have been somewhat damaged by the lack of carbonation. Taste might be a little on the sweet side. Tastes like fruitcake and stuff like that. Taste is less boozy than aroma. Maybe the booze evaporated. I cant tell. Oh well, life is weird. Cant give this as high a rating as I would have liked.

Bottle generously gifted by jaywahk73, an appreciator of fine Belgian ales. Thanks a lot, Jeff!

Served in my Corsendonk tulip.

The appearance is a mostly transparent brown hue, with sunset orange highlights apparent when held to the light. A gentle pour yields nearly a half inch of head that displays lasting retention and leaves ample lacing on the glass.

The aroma is fantastic and instantly identifiable as a quadrupel. Dark fruits, Belgian yeast, malt, spice...just wonderful.

The taste is quite good. Fortunately, I have most of the 750 mL bottle left to sip over the next hour or two. The taste brings a prominent yeast flavor, as well as dark fruit and dark Belgian ale characteristics. Additionally, the beer has an underlying sweetness one would expect from a quad, and a hint of warming alcohol. Brown sugar and figs are in there as well. Nice and complex, a wonderful sipper.

The feel is really smooth and quite well done. Impressive. Alcohol content is disguised well. Carbonation level is moderately high, but not overly so.

This beer has some pretty mixed reviews. Perhaps there is some deviation in bottles and/or batches. I know the bottle I am enjoying is fantastic. This is without question the best American quad I have had.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-15-2011

750 ml bottle from secret santa.  Thanks man!  Cork has a nice pop.  Pours a dark chestnut brown with a thick tan head.  Aroma of strong belgian yeast, chocolate, dark bread and dark fruits.  I get lots of earthy notes, some basement and mushroom notes.  Flavor is dark and sweet with rich chocolate and dark fruits.  The earthiness is present too with notes of mushroom.  Some brown sugar, some mild sweetness.  Spicy yeast notes as well.  Smooth, full, coating mouthfeel with soft, fine bubbles.  Finishes mildly sweet.  Nice beer.

Pours a deep ruby color with a thick tan head...decent retention.  Aroma is lightly fruity...dark cherry and fig...subdued sweetness and roasty malts.  Flavor has lots of fruity sweetness...fig, raisin, sherry notes...some roasty malt and good bitterness to balance nicely.  Mouthfeel is full and silky with a rich fruity/earthy bitter finish.

Draft at Spuyten Duyvil. Dark brown pour with a small head. Nose is surprisingly subtle, with touches of roast and caramel. The flavor is awesome, with big fig, prune, raisin, and delicious candied sweetness. Smooth, low to medium carbonation. Nice, but not in the upper tier of quads.

2008 vintage, corked bottle.  Pours a deep autumn brown with a nose of peach donut with chunks of orange rind.  Flavor is raisin bread with bready peach preserves.  Thick and chunky.  This vintage at this time leaves a musty attic essence.  Nice beer.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: 750 ml bottle pours brown with a tan head.  Aroma of malt, yeast and fruit.  Taste is slightly sweet, roasted malts and a hint  of yeast.

750ml bottle thanks to Gription79!  Pours a hazy majogany with a big tan head.  Aroma has raison, port, candied sugar, caramel, and dried fruit.  Taste is sweet with more fruit and some molasses. Full bodied and sticky.  This is about as good an American quad as Ive had.

Full flavors of a real  quality Belgain Ale complex flavors with total richness. Smooth and chewy as expected. Nice complexity of the full flavors a quality Belgain Ale side by side with the Abt 12 and this one blew it away. Recommended !
10th July 2009Hazy red brown beer. Light semi dry palate with a soft edge. Sweet caramel malt and sweet biscuits. Finishes dry, soft and frothy. A little sweet aniseed. Really enjoyed this.

Deep reddish plum pour off white creamy little frothy head ... bottle was settled and poured right but yielded a lot of head .... aroma of dark fruity yeast, candi sugar, caramel malts ... mouthfeel is creamy .... taste is of dark fruity yeast with a spicy bite, caramel malts, candi sugar ... pretty sweet with a dry spicy bite in the finish and a warming abv boozy feel as well .... good stuff just a tad too sugary

750mL c&c new label. Hazy maroon pour with weaker, bubbly beige foam. Sweet black cherry dessert nose with raisin and fig. Mild celery. Taste is tangy black cherry, mild chocolate, huge drying bitterness, mineral water, celery cell wall, tannic tea leaf. Interesting. Mild black cherry liquor. Effervescent palate. Not bad. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Very nice Quad. Dark copper with thin head. Excellent mix of the usual quad flavors: dried fruit, plum, lightly roasted malt,..  I will probably have another before the tap runs dry.

Pours a deep dark brown with a thin, tan, bubbly head. Aroma is raosty. The taste is of carmel. Sweet, brown sugar, molassas. Dark fruits, Plum. Slight spice presents. Light carbonation. Pretty darn good.

a smooth syrupy strong cough medicine sort of brew with the accompanying fruity type flavor and the warming almost stingy finish. flavor suspended in the mid palate like there is a layer of malt surrounding it. malt aroma.

Big rocky, foaming, crackling head.  Very good aroma of toasted grain, flowers, and molasses mingled with some tangy yeast.  SH has brewed up a delicious quad!  This is every bit as good as most of the Belgian quadrupels I have tried.  Flavors of cola, molasses, nuts, smoky malts, mellow yeast, bran muffings, Ukrainian honeycake - yum!  Pretty darn near flawless I would say.  Maybe it could have uses a little more floral or fruit flavors, but I quibble here.  Awesome brew, and one of Southamptons best.
Draft. Seep black/ broiwnish color. Very boozy after the sweetness of it. Definitely a high abv beer. Really good
Deep brown in color with a fuzzy and foamy tan color head. Malty and full of deep fruit flavors (raisin, plum, dates, nuts) with a strong full finish.

The smell is very complex, pulling out exotic spices and herbs, flowers and smoke. Very interesting on the nose. Color is amber. Has a nice texture the lingers on the tongue. Notes of brown sugar, flowers, rich and sweet malts.

This is very unique. I enjoyed it and would try drinking it again, although it is not on the top of my list.
0.75l - Nice lace, yeasty nose, candy sugar and booze.  Three distinct flavor periods per sip.  I had this right on the heels of a Chimay Bleu, making the goodness I found more remarkable.

Clear dark brown. This has some of the markings of a great big, dark Belgian: raisiny, plummy goodness and all that. The downside is its a bit too rich, I think. Cloying, perhaps. But it doesnt wear its 10% on its sleeve.

Bottle @ home with Justin, courtesy of wavers1. Huge thanks, Baker! Cloudy, caramel brown appearance with a foamy, tan head that dissipates somewhat quickly. Rich candy sugar, thick caramel, brown sugar, moderate fruity estery aroma. Very rich, thick syrupy caramel, rich candy sugar, plum/fig/dark fruity, very sweet flavor. Quite thick and syrupy which is somewhat off putting. Glad I got to try it but I am a little disappointed. Honestly, I wonder if my bottle just sat a little too long. Ill seek it out again because I think this has a chance to be a real winner.

750ml shared by MartinT.
Appearance : Clear shining copper with small bubbly head.

Aroma : Spices with red fruits and some caramel. Brown sugar with lots of spices. A bit yeasty. 

Palate : Pretty much flat.

Taste : Sweet caramel with nice malt. Brown sugar with spices. Spicy finish with more brown sugar and light hops. Enjoyable finish but quite sweet.

Overall : Not bad but not very refined. Carbonation is very soft, especially for the style. A bit too sweet even if it had time to mellow (this was 3-4 years old). A bit of a disappointment.
Dark brown in color with a large beige head. Aroma is of malt, plum, prunes, raisins, yeast, and toffee. Taste is of alcohol, candy sugar, caramel, raisin, light leather, malt, plum and bread dough.

750 ml corked and caged bottle shared by Fidel (thanks Jon) poured a clear reddish brown with a small lasting tan head. Aromas of carmel, toffee, plum and raisin. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of toffee, plum, raisin, light carmel and light spice with a smooth lingering dark fruit finish.

Opened a bottle. great fruit and port fragrance, cola color with nice head and lacing despite alcohol content.  Lots of dried fruits, grapes, and wine notes and quite sweet.  Finish is pleasant and syruppy honey.

A nice medium brown body with a tan head.  Head was a few shades lighter than body.  Retention was good and lace was great.  Aroma had strong malty notes.   Nice sweet caramel malts, brown sugar and wheat bread.  Dough notes from the yeast.  Flavor was initially sweet almost cloying.  The yeast had enough fruit notes and dough notes to smooth out the beer.  Carbonation was adequate.  Finish was medium dry.

Beautiful dark brown color. Carmel and malty tones. Toffee. No heavy alcohol flavors. Very drinkable. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

750 mL bottle courtesy of jtclockwork and shared at the 15th Richmond Ratebeer Gathering, 7/16/11. Pours a hazy amber color with a large tan head. Good head retention and lacing. Aroma of tart citrus, stone fruits, toasted malts and caramel. The taste is sweet bready notes, caramel, stone fruits, bitter hop finish. Medium-full bodied. Very nice.
tap at the Gate - sweet caramel, sticky sugars, strange roast and soda-pop with some herbal, hay and grassiness. Has a pepsi-like sweetness, which is overdone.

Thanks to dkachur for bringing this wish list beer to the Richmond Gathering.  Im a sucker for a good Southampton beer, and this one hit the spot for me.  Medium amber, slight haze.  Lightly fruity and spice aroma.  Flavor is vanilla, apricot fruit, and Belgian yeast spice notes.  Really good stuff, loved this beer.  Maybe not the best thing at the tasting, but it did hit a good note for me.
Fig aroma. Murky ochre, thick yellow head. Fig flavor. solid quad, but hard to compare with trappist versions.
Clear brown with amber highlights.  This is actually really good.  sweet and maltly.  Mucky belgian yeast.   Pretty good, but not as good as st. bernardus abby 12

Aroma: super fruity, dates and figs, dark sugars, caramel and toffee.  Pours dark burgundy with some haze, lots of off-white head and amazing retention, a 1/4" layer of foam persists through the drink.  Flavor is heavy on the fruity esters, lots of figs, plum, raisins, also a good dose of caramel and dark sugar.  Little to no hop bitterness or flavor, nice mild residual sweetness with a fairly dry finish.  The booze is very well hidden, very minimal hot alcohol and easy to drink.  Medium body with very high carbonation, quite prickly on the palate.  A very tasty beer.

750ml bottle, shared by a good friend.  Thanks Joel.  It is difficult to reproduce Belgian ales.  Many have tried, but this  is something best left to brewers who truly understand the essence of these liquid masterpieces.  In this case, I believe Southampton got it right!  The ale pours a dark brownish-red.  Head is medium and off-white, quickly dissipating to a small ring around the glass.  Aroma is Belgian yeast, bread, malt, dark fruit and spices.  Taste is delicious, with malt, sweet carmalized candy sugar and dark fruit.  Finish is smooth and sweet with just a touch of boozy warmth.  This is a nice ale, perhaps the best quadruple Ive tasted; aside from those originating in Belgium.  This brewery continues to produce delicious Belgian inspired ales.  I just wish we could buy them in Arizona.

First of all, I was able to enjoy this with close friends, Reg and family.  That always makes a beer good.  Wow this is a great Quad, especially since its American made.  Bready yeasty and malty nose.  Very complex beer, lots of flavors.  Candied dark fruits, prunes, vanilla, warming alcohol.  Rich and full palate.  Amazing brew!  I would swear it was made in Belgian.  Very impressed with this brewery.

Pours out of bottle, dark blackish red pour with white head, aroma has notes of big dark fruit with raisin, fig, dates, some slight white grape.  Taste has a pepper, yeasty spice, lots of dark fruit and lots of dark malt with a nice spicy dry finish. Good stuff.
Bottle. Dark brown / reddish pour with a nice thick head. Aroma is dominated by dark fruits - fig and blackberry. Taste is dark fruit, belgian yeast, bread, carmelized sugar, and quite sweet.

750 c&c pours a dark brownish red with a short lasting beige head.  Aromas of sweet malt and dried fruits.  Tastes of raisin, chocolate, and sweet malt, with some toasty notes.  Nice warm alcohol finish that leaves a lingering sweetness on the finish.  Overall, a very nice quad, holds up to the best of Belgium.

Is this beer a joke or satire? It has little to no aroma and tastes like sugar water. Save your money, this is a drain beer. And the description is a laugh! Dont these people know even the basics about Belgian beer?

Appearance:  Pours a reddish dark brown with a white fluffy head that subsides to an 1/8 inch film.

Aroma: Yogurt covered dark fruit and Belgian yeast.

Taste: Burnt sugar, pecan, spicy hops, dark bread. Finishes semi-sweet.

Mouthfeel:  Thick with high carbonation.

Overall:  A very well done Belgian-style Quad, not anything like Westy or St. Bernardus Abt 12 or Rochefort 12.
Ugly medium brown, tons of carbonation... Nose of spice, candied sugar, figs... Watery taste of candied sugar and caramel, ok, but not worth having again
Bottle. Pours black. Tan head. Nose and taste of date, raisin, alcohol, caramel malt and molasses. Earthy and malty. Lots of dried fruits. Rich brew. Complex.

From bottle at tasting.  The color was a deep dark ruby red with a puffy off white head that slowly disippated and left some lacing.   Aroma is lightly fruity, along with candied sugar and spiced dark maltiness.  Taste is sweet with strong esters and malt character.  Strong date flavor followed by raisins, hints of anise and earthiness, plus a slightly boozy tinge in the finish and an alcohol warmth. The bitterness is just enough to balance the sweet malt and alcohol flavors.  The body is full, almost syrupy and slightly overcarbonated.

Murky brown, decent staying head of tan, orange/light brown highlights, spotty lacing, occasionally very nice lacing.  Bread, funky nose, raisins and sweetness and yeasty sour in the nose.  Sweet, sugary taste, dries out nice at the end, but is it too sweet?  Very rich taste, very big, dont detect alcohol except the warming.  I have mixed feelings on this one.  Not as good as some other quads Ive had but still pretty good effort.

750ml, corked & caged bottle, courtesy of jtclockwork as part of Ratebeer free beer contest week. thanks, james! pours a hazy, burgundy with a huge, fluffy, beige head with great retention that leaves thick sheets of lace. aroma is great with rich belgian yeast, pumpernickle bread crusts, raisins, figs, and light caramel backed by notes of wheatgrass, plums, roasted pecans, and hints of cedar. flavor is wonderful as well with sweet pralines, dried figs, raisins, and subtle citrus up front backed by toasted bread, yeast, apple turnover, and hints of cocoa with just a touch of roasted malt on the finish. palate is on the fuller side of medium bodied with full carbonation and a fruity, dry, yeasty finish. overall, a great quad.

Bottle shared by bhensonb. Pours reddish brown with a massive tan head and an alcohol and dark fruit aroma. There is a rich fruit and caramel malt flavor with some carbonation and tingly alcohol finish. Tastes a lot like a Westy 12, but not quite as much depth to the flavor. Thanks for sharing this one Bill.

750 c&c from Half Time. BB 12/22/14. Pours mahogany with a creamy beige head. Sort of a scorched fruit/malt aroma. Followed by dark fruit. Full bodied. Smooth dark malt and fruit of the darker sort. Stacks up to the best Belgian quads. Finishes dry and perhaps lightly bitter. Great drink.
Not overly syrupy or boozy, even for a Belgian.  This is one I could probably have for a while without it coming off as being overly rich.

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2011 Poured from a 750ml at Maggies Attic.  Dark pour with a big frothy head on top.  Thick lacing.  Great head retention.  Big Belgian yeasty flavors with candi sugars, vanilla, and dark fruit.  The dark fruit is more secondary than expected, although certainly there, with raisins, figs, and plums.   The yeast, vanilla, and sugary flavors seem to stand out along with a controlled alcohol tang.  This is perhaps a little too sweet but still a really solid Quad here.  I went for a couple of pours of this at a tasting.
Raisins, brownie, plum, date, really excellent and complex. Slight burn in the finish but who cares? This is awesome!!

(750ml bottle best by 12/23/14) clear ruby/plum color with thick lasting creamy medium tan head. Nose of raisin, Belgian yeast, cream, rum, plum, sweet caramel. Taste of sweet raisin, very lightly spicy from the Belgian yeast, orange rind, mild bitter bite, and sweet cherry. Syrupy, well carbonated body and very sweet linger. Complex smelling and absolutely not indicative of the 10%.

On tap at the gate, from 2003!!!   The aroma is veery fruity, brown sugar, caramel.  The appearance is an opaque red/brown, thin tan head.  The flavor is stiky sweet, fruit, caramel, brown sugar, very good.  The finish is boozy, sweet, light pine hops.  Medium/thick in body, oily.  Very, very good.  Not sure if the aging (7-8 years) substantially changed this beer or not.

Aroma: Caramel, toffee, raisins, sweet malt.

Appearance: Clear, coppery pour, with a dense, tan head. Decent lacing.

Taste: Raisins, toffee, sweet caramel malt, fruity esters, Belgian yeast, alcohol. A little sweet. Cherry notes in the finish.

Palate: Medium mouthfeel. A little sticky.

Overall: Almost like a really strong dubbel. Tasty, a little woody. Nice.

I guess this is supposed to be along the lines of St. Bernardus Abt or Rochefort 10. If thats the case, it fails on every count. Even the colour isnt right, being a good bit too pale. The aroma is bland, but fortunately doesnt betray the horror of the taste. Way too sweet and lacking any complexity. Where are the dark fruit flavours? Wheres the bitterness? Wheres the balance?

A terrible attempt at one of my favourite types of beer.

Tap @ The Gate.
Brown/amber with bit of head. Aroma is strong and very complex with some vanilla, fruity, cherries, hint of a sour note. Sweet up front with some wood and some more fruit. Cherries and some malt come out more. Lots going on. Sweet fruity finish.
Bottle shared by hellbilly.  Brown pour with no head. Aroma of molasses, syrup, raisin bread and yeast. Flavor is sweet and fruity, but not much else.
Bottle thanks to ygtbsm94: Poured a coppery orange amber with off white head. Aroma is sticky fruit. Taste is fruit with burnt malt, some alcohol in the finish to set it off.

750 ml. Deep amber/copper body. Off-white head, rapidly diminishing. The aroma contains notes of caramel, molasses, banana, clove, candy sugar, plum, citrus, earniness. The flavor is heavily sweet, lightly bitter and lightly acidic. It finishes moderately sweet, lightly bitter and lightly acidic. Medium body, watery texture turning velvety, lively carbination. Enjoyable beer. Lacks some of the complexity for a big quad. Missing the mustiness. Plus it is overly sweet.

GABF 2010.  Pours from the bottle a dark brown color with reddish-hues and a decently formed tan head.  The aroma is nice even though huge sweetness is evident.  Dark fruits, candi sugar, and spices.  On the flavor, oh man, its like drinking liquified brown sugar.  Really sweet.  I dont mind sweet beers, but this is a little too much.  Fig, raisin, roast, and Belgian yeast flavors.  Fairly full-bodied with a good level of carbonation.  Theres a lot of good stuff going on here, but man, tone that sweetness down.

Bottled, of course. Poured a very dark brown to black with medium head. Caramel, dark fruit, licorice, yet somewhat subtle, some yeast etc.  Not too much carbonation and heavy yet nonobtrusive mouthfeel. Sweeter rather than bitter A good one and alco wasnt too apparent despite level.

750ml bottle from BOTW. I had to struggle to remove the cork, and it released all of a sudden spewing froth all over my kitchen. Pour is dark brown with plenty of bubbles and head from the ejected cork. Aroma is alcoholic raisins and brown sugar. With a healthy dose of alcohol. Flavors add yeast and bread notes to the dark fruit flavors. Very nice.
750 thanks to Matt. I was surprised how sweet this was. Some grape and plum but also some serious Belgian candi sugar. This bottle was one year old.

Serving: 750 ml. bottle from Julios Liquors. 
Aroma: The nose is spicy with a bit of dusty yeast and florals. 
Appearance: It pours a hazy brown with a large pillowy light tan head. 
Taste: The taste is surprisingly malty with a bit of yeast, dark fruit notes, date, fig, and slight florals.  A bit of roastiness and almost dark bubble gum comes out as the beer warms. 
Palate: Light to medium bodied with lots of softer carbonation leading to a dry, dusty finish. 
Overall: I loved how this brew evolved as I drank it.  Certainly one worth trying and dont limit yourself just to a small sample.  Have an entire glass.  Better yet, make it two.
Bomber.  Nice dark brown color with a huge head.  Tastes of dried fruit and carmal.  Very high carbonation.  A very nice beer.

Bottle. Dark brown / reddish pour with a nice thick head. Aroma is dominated by dark fruits - fig and blackberry. Taste is dark fruit, belgian yeast, bread, carmelized sugar, and quite sweet. Good stuff.

75cl corked bottle from a trade. All appearance and aroma reminded me of a good quad. The flavor is where it fell a little short. VERY sugary; not really sweet, just very much like raw sugar. Finished with a little toasted malt, caramel and alcohol too. Pretty simple.

750mL Bottle. Big fluffy amber and henna dark brown pour, cloudy with a tall two fingers of rocky maroon-tinted head. Flavors are solid. Aroma somehow minimalized, but focusing on darkened, dried fruit. Heavy toasted caramel, maybe a bit too browned, with lots of strong sugars, figs, and dates, strong carbonation carrying classic Trappist yeast flavors and a range of pilsner-based minerals. I think the texture and balance are supreme, but find the overall toasted sugar, with a little too much umami, browness, and soy. Otherwise, a very solid and tight example.

750ml share by hellbilly  thanks Josh!  Pours deep dark amber with a half finger off-white head.  The nose is caramel and boiled vegetables.  The taste is brown sugar, caramel, light vegetables.  Medium bodied.  Interesting brew.  Too sweet for my tastes.

Had this at BCTC after the fest, back at the campsite.  Pours a clear old caramel brown with ruby highlights.  Ruddy malt and caramel, toasty with more sweetness.  Toast, plums, prunes, and old caramel.  Sweet and boozy.  Long toast and plum finish.
On tap at BCTC.  Tastes of brown sugar, black peppercorns, plums and some yeast.  slight booze.  Very enjoyable for my tastes and i think come fall and winter I will crave this beer even more.

Bottle from a trade with tgncc. Pours dark ruby red color with tan head. Aromas of dark fruits and molasses. Sweet molasses flavor with raisins and figs with some doughy yeast. Very nice, but a bit sweet. Medium body with prickly carbonation. Thanks Tom.

750 ml bottle @ redlight redlight.  Spicy molasses with hints of licorice on the nose, smells great.  Pours a very dark amber with a thick long lasting off white head.  Very smooth and malty, rich dark caramel with hints of molasses, spicy yeast notes, cinnamon and allspice with dried dark fruits, prunes and dates, finishes very dry though.  Excellent!

year old bottle by way of hmmiexist shared (luckily) on 7/4/10.

dark rich copper colored pour with an off white head.

odd smell?... red peppers (not spicy), black peppercorns, brown sugar, herbs, iced tea florals and yeast.

the palate is terribly sweet.... atrociously so...the sugar content makes me twitch... flavors of brown sugar, umami woodiness and red peppers with a bitter grainy finish.

this is really hard to swallow... 6/4/4/2/11/2.7
A decent offering, well worth the money and id possibly get it again. Just didnt knock my socks off. Not much to make it memorable, dark fruits, dry, yeasty esters, pretty standard.

Cork pops off easily, almost foams over. Red-amber body, huge puffy white head that gets in the way. Aroma is a bit watery, apple, spice, nut, and tea. Flavor is metallic and heavily sweet, sugary and with a bit of booze in the back, also some caramel and cherry before the dry breadloaf finish. Fizzy carbonation stings the tongue, odd given the sweetness in the profile. Not very complex, definitely showing some alcohol, and a bit muddled.

Bottle pour to Trappist glass gives dark brown clear color with thick very long lasting beige head.  Aroma dark fruits, bread.  Heavy taste of dark fruits, plum, spice, sweet malts, Belgian yeast.  Alcohol apparent but not overwhelming.  Palate thick, chewy and carbonated.  Finish long lasting with light bitterness.

This is a fairly heavy complex quad and theyve done a nice job with it.  Its rather like eating a meal though.  If you are looking for something light look elsewhere.

Bottle at Governors Island Brewfest. This was great stuff. Poured a dark, ruby-brown with a voluminous, beige head. Dark fruit-heavy aroma with raisins, prunes, dates and figs, plus some malty caramel. Flavor is very sweet but not outrageous, with plenty more dark fruit and a present though not overbearing Belgian character. Full-bodied with average carbonation and nice warmth. Light bitterness in the finish but the lingering impression is one of sweetness and dark fruits. Great beer.

Sampled at American Craft Beer Fest 2010. Pours brown with a thin beige head.  Aroma of spicy yeast, some dough, and a little hops.  This beer has a good combination of the hops, malt, and yeast flavor.  Definitely recommended.

Bottle, via trade with tgncc,big foamy tan head over dark brown
body, aroma has a lot of caramel, dark fruits and candied sugars,
flavors of malty caramel, fruit and lots of chocolate, fruity chocolate
finish

Bottle at Mr. Beerys in Sarasota. Pours clear brilliant mahogany with copper edges and tan head. The aroma is rich and full with sweetness carried by sugar stewed raisins, figs and prunes as well as a spicy note or two. The taste is also full and rich and a touch prickly with carbonation. I get prunes, raisins, some figs and a few mildly drying notes like roastiness and spices. Very nice and smooth.
Sample at Julios Spring Beer Fest (disclaimer - memory somewhat blurred after perhaps a few too many samples) Excellent for the style though I do find this style to be too sweet for me on the whole.

Bottle via trade from JB.  Thanks Jason!  Nose and flavor both are a really thick, dark fruit sensation of plum concentrate, date and "quad extract."  What a sweet, sweet impression of a good beer.  One note, but pretty good.

2007 sample on 4/1/10 at Ale Atlanta.  deep orange pour with a white head... very sweet nose with some candi sugar and dark fruits... medium body with raisin, plum, cherry notes, lots of sugar and apple... solid carbonation throughout... a bit too sweet - even after a couple years in the cellar.
Bottle on the shelf, dont believe they are brewed at the PH, Brune pour with a bit of off-white head.  Fruit, nut, and spice notes. Yeasts, nut and fruity flavors take over. Slight warming.

Loads of fig and raisin aroma, sweet before it becomes jammy.  Dark toffee colored, fizzy small head.  Little carbonic bite, mostly a milk caramel forward beer with plenty of dried fruits and a silky velvety finish.  Liking this more and more with each sip.  Tanned leather, dried figs, licking my lips with a smile.

750ml bottle from 2009.  Mostly clear reddish amber with a touch of red when help to the light.  Brew had a small beige ring for a head.  Candied apples and brown sugar in the nose.  Flavor was quite sweet with candied dark fruits and candie sugar, a good Quad, a little sweet for my taste.

Got to try this at a recent BA/RB tasting in Portland, OR. Colour... amber with very little head. Nose... biscuity with caramel and toffee. Palate... sweet, with hints of sugar sirop, toffee, golden raisins and spice cake.

750 ml. bottle from Greens on Ponce De Leon. Not much of a head on this. Thin wispy tan head. It has a "lighter" cola brown color. Subtle roast aroma mixed in with dark fruits, yeast, and a fairly pungent raisin aroma. Sugar makes itself known as well. New aromas are popping out at me at different times; now, I am getting a subtle fruity plum aroma. The light plum, burnt sugar, yeast, roast, raisins, and light alcohol flavors are mix quite well together. This is a definitely an assertive Abt. A little too hot at times. The texture is nice and rich. The roast flavor is a nice added twist to an Abt, but I like it. As it warms, I am getting a light grape flavor. A very nice Abt made by an American brewery is a winner in my book.

750ml bottle.  clear dark brown under a small beige head.  aroma is strong and sweet with lots of raisin, plums, licorice, anise, strawberry, caramel, and hints of chocolate.  the palate is between moderate to high carbonation and full bodied.  the flavor has most of what i mentioned from the aroma with some hints of rum and just a tiny hint of tart green apple  but not enough to even produce anything undesirable.  maybe just a tad too much residuals hanging around.  a sweet dessert beer.  nicely done.

Sampled from the bottle at the 2010 February Circle City Tasting. Poured a near clear golden brown with a medium off-white head. Aroma was full of sweet grains, caramel and biscuit. Flavor was similar with sweet notes throughout, caramel, grain and honey. There was a bit of an alcohol undertone. A bit overly sweet for my liking.

Sampled at Feb 2010 Indy tasting - Aroma is initially a tad oxidized but is quickly overtaken by caramel and prune.  Flavor is full of caramel, prune and raisin.  Palate is very smooth.  Ive had this bottle for at least 3 years and no telling how old it was.  Thinking I should have popped it earlier, but still a good brew.

Tastewise, one of the better U.S. quads Ive tried. Full bodied and little bit fizzy carbonation at first. After the carbonation dies down, the taste is a little bit too much caramel, otherwise Id rate this higher. All in all, a great release from Southampton.
Bottle (2007) at Sunes - Thanks. Clear red/brown - white head. Sweetness, brown sugar, nutty, fruity, over the top - old, soapy, igh carbonation, raisins, prunes, dried fruits, roasted, notes.

750mL bottle from Premier Gourmet in Buffalo. Pours a deep, hazy brown body with an amber tint when held to the light. Thin cream colored head with some lacing. Aroma is sweet caramel, malt, dark fruits, yeast with some alcohol notes. Flavor is initially very sweet caramel and fruits, candy-like with a great balance of malts and some yeast. Almost no carbonation, very smooth, full bodied. Very good, easy drinking beer throughout. A bit too sweet, but overall really nice with almost no sign of the 10%ABV present.

750mL bottle sampled against two versions of St. Bernardus Abt 12, thanks for this one Dan!  Pours This one poured a murky mahogany brown with an off white beige head. Aroma was dark fruits, and spices. Taste was overly sweet with taste of dark fruits, spice and port notes. Initially enjoyed the sweetness, but after continued drinking it became a bit overbearing, otherwise a great beer.

Really nice quad.  Pours dark rich burgandy with miimal head.  ARoma of plums, figs, syrup, slight wine element?  It is a very sweet beer, with syrupy texture and excellent mouthfeel.  Caramel, brown sugar flavour, with dark fruits. Amoungst my favourite quads thus far.

Thanks corey70! - Pours a dark amber with a large lt beige head...aroma is cherry and raisin, vanilla...as it opens, the alcohol and acid become more apparent, quite inviting...flavour is smooth and creamy, plummy, vanilla oak and brown sugar, sweetness is cut by the ample abv...boozy but not hot or detracting, tiny little bubbles... just delicious...

750 ml bottle from BOTW shared with Josh, served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass. SE 22/09.
App.:  Fairly deep copper, hazy, large, loose light tan head.
  
Aroma:  Bright berries and tree fruits, sweet caramel/treacle, slight warm spices and wood, some dried fruits, some light citrus.
  
Palate:  Medium body, very full and lively effervescence.
  
Flav.:  Very sweet and fruity, much like the nose with slightly more wood, lots of rum-like notes, brown sugar and caramel; sweet with balancing bitterness, slight wooden, malty finish.

A pretty nice example of the style.

This one poured a murky mahogany brown with an off white beige head. Aroma was dark fruits, roasted, spices and alcohol. FLavor was sticky sweet upfront with the dark fruits coming through, finish was dry and spicey with a lingering but not overbearing alcohol presence.

From a 1.5 year old bottle, and actually the first example of this beer that Ive had.
Deep almost burgundy color--looks very much like maple syrup--with a small white head that dissipates quickly.  Smells remind me of candied figs and apricots, but theres also some vanilla here. Theres a rum called, I believe, sailor Jack, which has a very similar and appealing aroma.  
When it comes to taste, the same flavors hinted in the aroma come through, with the addition of a distinct cinnamon element.  Its a big beer and you really get the volume here with a lot of syrupy bigness. A previous reviewer called out toffee and I think thats spot on. 
Finish lingers with a seriously raisin taste. Very good beer, but after one glass Im satisfied.  I think this is one to split.

Having this fresher and now having a six year old bottle. Ages well, more fruit and a hint of tartness but works. Aroma is sweet and fruity with some spice. Flavor is sweet with some caramel, molasses and spice. Really nice balance and great flavor.

Copper/red color with a viscous tan head. Nice earthy Belgian yeast, pit fruit aromas. Smooth medium body. Good earthy yeasty spice flavors with caramelized brown sugar, light pit fruits and a trace of smoke. Nice rendition. Thanks to notalush for this bottle.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: The DanJournal #261.  750ml bottle.  Tasted 6/8/09.  Hazy with a ruby brown hue.  Off-white head.  Sweet malty aromas.  Hints of toffee and truffles.  Nice berry esters.  Full bodied with big dark berry esters.  Toffee flavors with a mild woody note.  Apples, melon and citrus.  Such a smooth transition between all the flavors.  Very well done!
750 mL bottle.  Brown pour with a thick tan head.  Aroma of Belgian yeast, caramel and brown sugar.  Taste of dark fruit, yeast, caramel and sugary apple.  Great finish with a faint hint of acohol.

Had this one at the RB Pittsburgh tasting.  Very thick on the pour, had some floaties.  Smells of booze and fruit...perhaps a bit too much booze.  Still manages to be refreshing, which is unusual for a quad.  Good!

She poured with no head or discernable foam. A few scattered bubbles can be seen lazily floating across her glassy surface which refracts rich mahogany wood with hints of deep garnet highlights. Swirling the contents in my glass has no effect on her head, but it does release a pungently thick cloud of super-sweet maple syrup with a side offering of molasses. Aunt Jemima anyone? As I try to work my way past the basin of maple syrup, some dark, pitted fruits can be found gasping for air: dates, figs, and prunes. Dark breads are drenched in maple syrup and sprinkled with cinnamon and nutmeg along with, interestingly enough, a dry herbal finish which brings to mind rosemary and thyme. Im a bit leery as I dive into her depths and am met by an awaiting sea of maple syrup and molasses, thick, super-sweet, and instantly mouth-coating to the point of being overly cloying. She is far too sweet for my tastes and really too sweet for the style. Did I get a bad bottling? Supping onward, as I tread through all the maple, I occasionally stumble across some raisin bread, prunes, and dates. There is no discernable carbonation which furthers my concern that I am tasting a bad bottling. The faint esters of spice and herbs which were in her nose are nowhere apparent in her palate. As I choke down the last of my Southampton Abt 12 I am left highly disappointed and wishing for some St. Bernardus Abt 12 to make things right again.


After speaking with my good friend Eric, I am seriously considering the bottle I tasted to be a fluke. The only way I will be able to find out for sure is to hunt down another bottle of the Abt 12 from Southampton and give her another tasting. If there is no difference though, then I will stand by my lackluster and smothered impression of this fancily packaged bottle of maple syrup. Pancakes anyone?
(am on lookout for a new bottle to taste and compare)
750.  Pours a brown body with a tan head.  Very rich and chewy with dark etoh latent fruit.  A raisin, chewy caramel with a fruity apple caramel body.  Finishes warm and full.  Awesome.

9/10/2008:  Southampton Abbot 12 doesnt have much aroma but is somewhat candy-like.  It pours a transparent pecan color with a n airy beige head.  The visible carbonation level is mild to moderate.  The beer tastes slightly corked.  It is sweet up front with good caramel and fruit in the flavor.  This beer is high in alcohol, but that is well-blended with the other flavors.  It finished slightly dry and has a bubbly champagne mouthfeel.
 750 mL bottle (Alc 9.9% by Vol.) from moejuck.  Thank you!  Rating #335 for this beer.

2006 750ml bottle.  Aroma of aged dark malt laced in thick alcohol.  Mellow carbonation.  Thick, rich raisin malt taste.  Sweet and thick, quite true to style.  Deep dark fruit tastes.  An excellent sipper.

Bottle. Pours slight hazy brown coloured with a creamy light brown head. Aromas of dried fruit, caramel, molasses sugar and licorice. Very sweet and warming flavour with notes of raisins, sugar, caramel and a little vanilla. Overall too sweet and too sticky.

UPDATED: JUL 1, 2009 Bottle@ Track 84, Warwick, RI. Pretty sweet and caramelly. Very nice, but miles away from the best Belgian versions of this style. Some caramel, banana esters, toffee, alcohol, and some brandy notes. Actually a bit cloying towards the end

Hazy amber with a small off-white head. Aroma of bready malt, prunes, licorice and brown sugar. Really sweet flavoour, sugar and caramel notes, with a toouch of prunes. The sweetness is soon very cloying.

2003 courtesy of HogTownHarry. Cork   slid off easily with little pop. Sweet malty alcohol aroma. Dark brown with no head. Sweet yet dry, smooth, carbonated, dark fruity cherry, blueberry raisin malt. First taste is cherry, ends with blueberry raisin taste. Surprisingly dry raisin aftertaste.

From the 750ml bottle it pours a dark brown color with an amber hue topped by a small, bubble beige colored head. Some lines of lacing mark the glass. The aroma shows sweet caramel, raisins, figs, and molasses. The flavor follows suit with the sweet caramel and raisins dominating.  Figs, vanilla, and brown sugar add more sweetness to the profile. Not much in the way of hops. Medium full bodied and a syrupy mouthfeel with a warm, sweet finish from the alcohol. A nice beer, but a bit too sweet for my liking.

75 cl. Bottle. Thanks to Maxxdaddy. Pours a cloudy amber with a fluffy white head and lacings. Fruity, vinous and strong. Warmth from alcohol. Lots of toffee, fruit and caramel. Smooth and sticky. Overall heavy and quite nice.

Bottle:  Color is a stunning blend of amber and chestnut with a finger of creamy beige head.  Rich aroma is sweet with caramel, dark fruits, toffee, and light yeast.  The taste is lively with fruitiness and Belgian spices.  Candied sugar, caramel, and toffee.  A light floral presence and bready malts.  This really is an interesting cross section of flavors.  So much going on, yet well balanced and the warming feel sneaks up on you.  Thanks to Sloth for sending this fun brew.

Hazy, deep amber appearance with a large beige head that  flattened out pretty quickly and left little lacing.  Sweet aroma of caramel malts and ripe fruit.  Yeasty, doughy taste with honey, dark fruit and toffee competing for attention.  Smooth, full bodied, decently carbonated mouthfeel.  Big alcohol punch delivered in the lingering finish.

UPDATED: MAY 5, 2009 Holy wow.  I found this beer absolutely phenomenal.  I drank it later in the same evening that I had the Westy 12, Bernardus 12, and Rochefort 10, and frankly thought it blew all three out of the water.
Bottle shared by Hophead22 by way of phhd..Pours a red brown with no head.. Smell is fruity, cherries.. Very sweet with no carbonation.

The cork popped and it bubbled out with carbonation pours a nice amber color. The smell was nice and  sweet  was and pleasant to the nose. You can taste cherries, honey, and complex sugars a great quad that in almost on par with st bernardus and Rochefort 10.

Bottle shared by Hophead22.  Pours a hazy dark red with no head.  Aroma is black cherries and raisins with some bread and spice.  Flavor is very sweet like honey and a bit grainy, maybe some dark sugars as well.  Thick and full bodied, however there is virtually no carbonation.  Tasty stuff but the lack of carbonation was a downer.

750ml bottle thanks to phhd, thanks Ethan. Shared with DuffManSW and mspindler. Dark amber with hints of gold. 
Big belgian yeast aroma. Very sweet, some alcohol warmth, pretty decent.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text:
750mL bottle courtesy of shaebs99 labeled 9.9% ABV on the bottle, poured into a snifter.

When I "popped" the cork, I was a little suspicious things might be off as there was nary a sound.  The cork just slid right out.  An aggressive pour yielded only a few big bubbles that recedes immediately leaving no ring and no lacing.  The color was a deep, clear brownish amber.  Not much life to this one.

Despite being a dead bottle, the aroma and taste were still good.  The aroma is very sweet with tons of candi sugar, fruity esters and dark fruits, especially raisins.  The alcohol burns the nostrils a little bit after a couple whiffs.

The taste is also very sweet with lots of raisins and brown sugar.  The dark malts really come out in the taste and a bit of spices in the finish, but nothing too over-the-top.

The mouthfeel is where my bottle has clearly suffered.  Its almost completely still with no carbonation whatsoever.  This makes for a slick and very thin mouthfeel that is subpar for the style, or any style.

This was clearly a bad bottle, but Ill stick with my review until I can find a good one to try.  The aroma and taste were clear indications of a very good quad underneath, but this one had completely lost its carbonation.

Bottle, thanks to EDA.  Reddish brown pour with some off-white head.  Aroma is ripe fruit, sweet and lightly sour, and yeasty cherries.  Flavor is the same, a slightly medicinal yeast finish.  Pretty good beer, strange mix of sweet and sour.

Barrel brown-amber with a diffuse head. Barrel-brown mallt base with sour, wood-aged aromatic notes, and fruity yeastiness with some cherry. Caramel apple flaovr, with strong, musky phenols that become preponderate. Sour-brownish ale on the finish.
My 11th rate of Abt/Quadrupel. And thats official. Copper color, nice head. Sweet aroma, dark fruit, sugars. Sweet flavors of caramel,  dark fruit, brown sugar and alcohol. Sweet and tasty!

Bottle @ chrisos Pre-GBBF Shindig 2008. Pours a slighlty hazy dark amber color with a small off-white head. Has a sweetish malty yeasty and slightly spicy aroma with some hints of alcohol. Sweetish malty fruity spicy yeasty dark fruit flavor. Has a sweetish malty yeasty finish with some hints of dark fruit in the aftertaste.

750ml bottle, traded for in August 2007, with thanks to john adam2002.  Pours a clear caramel color with a towering off-white head that lingers.  Aroma is sweet malts, candied dark fruits, caramel, and some lightly spicy belgian yeast.  Flavor starts heavy on the sweet, with candied dark fruits, caramel, some molasses and a hint of spicy yeast; pretty lively carbonation.  The sweetness is very distracting, and ultimately hurts this one.  Even aside from the sweet, theres nothing too exciting going on anyway, lacking any depth or complexity; disappointing.
Bottle at OTown throwdown.  Lots and lots of caramel, syrup, and molasses.  Felt like flat soda mixed with more sugar and syrup.

Thinner in appearance than I expected.  Hazy brown, but by no means opaque.  Complexity of flavor, dark roasts, hints of burnt coffee, real notes of sweet chocolate, malt, and a touch of alcohol but no real burn or heat.  Some dried fruit complexity as well.  Enjoyable, not remarkable, and not my favorite quad or my favorite strong beer.  I called it a very small quad" in my tasting notes.
Bottle from the Otown throwdown.  Brown pour, no head.  Aroma of molasses, syrup, raisin bread and yeast.  Flavor is sweet as hell, raisins, prunes and this bottle was pretty flat.  Too sweet.

FRO Throwdown: Caramel color with touches of ruby. Raisiny raisin bread nose with touches of pipe tobacco. Damned sweet! Near cloying. Candyish. Pretty under-attenuated, too heavy and needs more carbonation to lift it off the palate.
Enjoyed on Cape Cod, nice evening beer. Rich and mildly spicy hops with caramel and fruity undtertones and lots of heaty malts. Its very good.

C&PLYFOTD: Bottle, courtesy Phillybeer2112. Fuzzy clear head and spotty lacing. Very dark raisins and oats in the nose, with thick dry fruit and caramel. Rich oily hops in the mouth, with sweet molasses, and dark fruits in the finish. Nice and full-bodied, balanced and surprisingly hoppy.

Sample at O-town throwdown 09
pours hazy brown with thin beige head.
Aroma of caramel hops, yeast, notes of dark fruits.
Taste is yeasty, dark fruits as figs, prunes and some candi sugar. Thick grainy palate.

Sampled at C&P Otown Throwdown, big thanks to whoever brought this! Murky brown pour. Maple syrup, brown sugar sweet malt aroma. Taste is sweet brown sugar malt with a tangy bitterness. A little too sweet for me.

750 ml bottle - contract brewed; killer bonus from tweety after i missed my own bottle at a tasting (haha); pours flat, clear reddish brown; very sweet and watery thin; some like candy syrup and caramel; way too much on the sweetness factor for me; wow, what a disappointment and easily topped by boulevards sixth glass in a side by side

2007 Bottle via trade with hopdog (thanks!). Definitely different for an abt/quad. Pours a clear ruby brown with a white head. Nose is super fruity, molasses jumps out, as do caramel notes. Cherries and apples, sugar. Nice carbonation levels. Taste is definitely sweet, very smooth and the alcohol is well hidden. Nice and fruity, sweet. Will definitely give this one another go. Very much unlike the other quads that are out there. Nice.

Bottle, sampled at Woodshop Quad. Pours a clear dark brownish-amber with a white ring. Rich aroma, of malt, dark fruits, molasses, and alcohol. Taste is big and sweet, of malt, molasses, brown sugar, spice and dark fruits. Lingering sweetness. Very nice.

2006 bottle.  Darker brown with a big fig & merlot aroma that has lots of sugar and light hops in the nose.  Flavor is big and sweet with caramel, raisin, mild spice, and light hops.  Really nice quad - maybe the best US-made example of the style.

750 mL caged and corked bottle from 2006, unfortunately i dont remember whom it was courtesy of - acquired via trade and mellowed in the cellar for a couple years.  prune and pumpkin, red wine and raisin, slight alcohol heat and an overall caramel and dark brown sugar feel to the aroma.  caramel and yeasty alcohol dominate, with nuanced hops and darker fruit esters.  generally a sweet quad, which i think would be even better if given the opportunity to ferment out and dry up a little more.  a very nice beer, and would possibly improve in the bottle for years to come.

750. Ruddy brown pour with tall creamy head that has stuck around. Very sweet, stronger than the Bernardus. Nose is tart, dark fruit. Slight smokiness to flavor and very complex overall. A bit of holiday spice. Quite metallic, sharp and sticky sweet. Very nice, but not at the top of my list for quads; very respectable.
Pours reddish amber brown, sweet, dark fruit, molasses, little spice, slight bready.
UPDATED: JAN 21, 2009 Pours prune brown with no head. The nose and flavor were quite rich with dried fruit, especially figs, brown sugar and caramel. Smooth on the palate.

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2009 07 bottle thanks to EyeDrinkAle, thanks man!  Poured a deep copper-brown color with a thick, billowing, rocky beige head that slowly receded and left some spotty lacing.  Sweet aroma with some prunes, figs, raisin, a hint of leather, molasses, and brown sugar.  Sweet, smooth entry with hints of brown sugar and molasses with a faint earthy spiciness and a bit of light smokiness finishing with some honey and caramel sweetness.  Moderate carbonation and full on the palate.  Seems a bit sweeter than traditional quads, but it is tasty.  I would have preferred some sort of hoppiness or a bit more smoke to balance the sweetness.  Thanks again Mike.

C&C 750, shared by LooseCannon. Clear brown with a small brown head. Odd nose, like Red Man chewing tobacco, very sweet and very malty. Rather sweet flavors, raisins and whiffs of smokiness, sweet caramel. nice.

btl by Springslicker. Brown to ruby red pour with tan head and lace. Sweet spiced brown sugar aroma. Flavor of molasses a spiced almost pepper with a candy after taste. Carbonation is where it should be mouthfeel is solid. Very complezx flavor a bit like a Christmas mystery pie that has those spices you cant put your finger on thanks Jay

750 ml bottle shared by shigadeyo.  Pours a clear brown copper color with a medium sized beige head.  The aroma has some dark fruit, light spice, and sweet brown sugar.  The aroma was a tad bit underwhelming.  The flavor has a nice dark fruity character along with brown sugar sweetness and Belgian character.  Some of the abv shows toward the finish, but this is very drinkable.

750ml bottle.  Pours a dark brown with a ruby tine.  Huge off-white head.  Nose of vinous fruit and dark fruit.  Taste of candied and over-ripe fruit.  Mouthfeel is cloyingly sweet with slight alcohol and lots of carbonation.  I like quads, but this was sweeter than I would have liked.  Had wanted this one for awhile and was a little disappointed.  Still decent.

Bomber from sloth.  10%!!?, they must be mad.  Well disgused by all the spicy and grainy chewyness.  An active murky brown with a thick, thick head. Body is FULL ON and has quite a bit going on.  Fantastic on a negitive degree windy night.

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2009 750ml bottle from a recent trade (contract brewed edition not publick house).... pours a mostly transparent reddish raisin brown with a wispy,slightly off white head... aroma of dark fruits with sweet candied and brown sugar... candied sugar flavors with subtle dark fruit but the emphasis on the former more so than the latter.  diet soda lngering sweetness in the finish.  crisp clean ABT flavor albeit just a tad too sweet.

2007 bottle, aged about one year.  A hazy, dark chestnut brown colored body is crowned with a small, foamy, cream colored head.  Scant traces of jagged line lacing marks the glass.  Aromas include brown sugar, caramel, raisins, figs, floral hops, and mild, dark spices.  Flavors are very much the same, with sweet brown sugar and stewed raisins dominating.  Further sweetness comes from candied figs, dates, and vanilla, with very little balancing bitterness.  Dense and medium-full in the mouth, the sweet, syrupy body gets to be cloying.  This is a nice brew, but it is too over the top sweet to be a favorite of mine.

Dark amber pour, with a huge tan head. fruity, malty, and spice aroma. Big fruit and spice flavor with a slight alcohol warmth.
Big, and not an every day beer, but very very, good.

750 ML Bottle-Dark brown/mahogany color w/a moderate off white foamy head. Sweet, fruity, aroma. Fairly sweet, but very enjoyable; Flavors of candied sugar, malt, toffee, raisens, and dark fruit. Very smooth and easy to drink, long finish of a classic Belgian. Another winner from these folks. Alcohol was well hidden.

Pours a hazy, copper/brown colored body with a thick, soapy, white head. Spicy malt aroma with bananas, toffee, some vinous qualities. Flavors are pretty sweet caramel malt, toffee, raisins, coffee, and a very slight alcohol tinge.  A pretty good quad.
dark brown pour, not much head, nose is sweet, and so is the flavor, with some aging i think would be more complex but well done drinkable with no carbonation quad

(10/25/08) Bottle at the brewpub in Southampton. Deep ruby color with a medium beige head. Aroma of malt, caramel, plenty of dark fruits (plums, some grapes, raisins notes) and yeasty notes. Sweet malty flavor with caramel, brown sugar and dark fruits. A drier, slightly spicy and slightly alcoholic, finish. Rather full-bodied with lots of carbonation.
no head to speak of, but it sits on a nice reddish brown body.  flavor is very fruity, but a ripe fruitiness (cherries and raisens)rich and sweet, but not cloying.

Bottle thanks to JB175. Pours with a huge, fluffy, off-white head and a clear brown body (too light for the style). Good lacing. Aroma of dark fruits, brandy, bananas, pears, spices, some bubblegum, dates and molasses. Taste is sweet throughout with dark fruits some alcohol, spices, molasses, sherry, and raisins. Warming, with a creamy mouthfeel and lively bubbles.

The aroma contains definite alcohol with a hint of molasses and dough and dark fruits. The head is off-white and rocky with good lacing. The body is clear and bronze. The initial flavor is sweet with a long lightly bitter finish. The palate has a medium body, a syrupy finish, lively carbonation, and a heavily alcoholic feel.
bottle chris o’s. Malty aroma , dark sweet rasin and date notes with very fruity and syrupy long flavour. Some sweet bready yeast and good carbonation.

750 mL bottle shared by kiefdog.  Wow.  Big sweetness and flavor in this one.  Pours a dark brown/ amber color with a creamy off-white head.  Sweet caramel, sugar, bourbon, alcohol, and cinnamon in aroma.  Very syrupy mouthfeel with sugar in the flavor and finish, along with all of the qualities listed in the aroma.  Very distinguished quad.

Bottle shared by alexadad06. Poured a cloudy brown color with a large frothy off-white head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate tart citrus and brown sugar aroma. Medium to full body with a sticky texture and fizzy carbonation. Heavy bittersweet flavor with a medium to heavy bittersweet finish of moderate duration. Good complex brew.

75cl bottle from New Bayview Liquors (Boston, MA). Pours a dark brown to black with a one finger tan head. Aroma is sweet dark fruit, caramel, honey, some phenol. Flavor is much of the same with maple syrup-like flavors and sweet, slightly roasted malt. Generally syrupy mouthfeel and full body with a long sweet finish.

Bottle 75cl. @ chris_os Pre-GBBF Shindig 2008.Unclear medium amber color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, sweet, light to moderate hoppy and yeasty, orange. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and light to moderate bitter with a long duration. Body is medium to full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. (020808)

2006 Vintage Publick House Bottle, via trade guessing one of my ny trading buddies, whoever it was, thanks.  Pours dark brownish red with a tan ring.  Nose is sweet with touches of raisans.  Taste is sweet, with a deep vinious quality.  The booze is there, to a degree, but its well aged, and quite tasty.

Bottle from puzzl. Thanks Andy.  After removing the cage and prying out the firmly seated cork, this poured a deep red to amber color with virtually no head. Nose of sweet caramel malts and ripe fruit.  Very greasy mouthfeel more like port wine than beer.    Flavor is quite sweet, with raisins.  Finish is long, sweet and full of malts. Kind of a sipping beer, but was as good at the finish as at the end.  Overall very nice.

750ml - Poured a quite dark, clear reddish amber in color with a medium bright white head that settled to that creamy covering over the beer.  Some nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma is brown/candied sugar and sweet caramel malts.  Flavor is quite sweet with lots of dark fruit (raisins and prunes) ,but some lighter fruit (apples, berries) as well.  Finish is sweet and lingering.  Lacks some of the Belgian Abbot yeastiness that this style typically has, but I really like it a lot... excellent beer!

Brown hazy pour with lasting, whispy and foamy head.  Candied sugars and bready aromas are first noticed, then making way for prunes, berries, dried fruits and a tangy green apple touch.  Smoothed out body with brandyish hint, solid mouthfeel.   Decent complexity makes for a solid brew.
Dark, dark reddish brown body with a thin white head, this ale has caramel and raisin notes, a sweet half-note on the finish, and probably needs to rest for a year or two to reach its potential.

Bottle, 2008 Pre-GBBF Chris_o Shindig.  Rusty brown, lots of butter-colored head. Rose petals, mint, pears. Heavy raisin sweetness, a bit of iron. Not really bad, but far too thick and sweet for a quad.

Cola in colour with a bit of brown, a large lingering off-white coloured head, excellent lacing.  The aroma is malty, quite sweet, rich with a bit of noticable alcohol, lots of dark fruits.  The flavour is of candy sugar, lots of malt, again quite sweet, smooth, creamy, light alcohol.  Very sweet mouthfeel, medium body, medium/high carbonation.  Finishes long, sweet, malty.
Highly sweet but it didn’t seem to take anything away from what the beer was offering.  Nowhere near the amount of alcohol that I was expecting.  This one would age very well.
750ml bottle shared by rudolf, thanks Rudy.
Opened on March 28, 2008.
No date.

Bottle at chris_o’s poison arrow through my ass tasting. Alround tasting: Sweet, very sweet, fruity, candy sugar, alright. But seems to be lacking the right type of yeast to make it a very charactable(?) quad.

Chris_os GBBF Shindig August 08. 9.9% abv. Yeasty muddled aroma. Sugary sweet. A pleasant enough beer - feels like an imitation Belgian ale, which is what it is! Too sugary for my taste. But Im not a fan of yeasty, sugary Belgian ales anyway.
750ml bottle. Pours clear reddish brown in color with thin white head. Aroma sweat, caramel, fruity and malty. Taste sweat, malty and fruity with sweat and clean finish.

Bottle. Pours amber red with a beige head. Sweet aroma with raisin and berry. Also a bit of yeast and caramel. Smooth body. Sweet fruity flavor with berry, raisin, and prune, as well as a bit of yeast. Nice.

Deep brown in color with a thin off-white head this dissipated.  The nose is dominated with sweet caramel, raisin, chocolate and roasted malt.  In the mouth it was medium to full-bodied, rich and dense.  The palate was also sweet and came off candied.  While balanced it was definitely an end of the night beer.

dark brown with mild head for the style.  flavor is dominated by the dark candi sugar.  some crystal malt also in there.  no real hop character.  the alcohol is definitely present adding a complexity.  this is a very good example of an abbey quad, but my bottle needed to age two years or so for the candi sugar to mellow to allow some more complexities to develop.  a ton of potential though

Pours clear amber with copper hues. A half inch head of white quickly dissolved leaving behind a few dots of lacework and a ring around a placid surface.

Aromatics lead off with raisins, sweet toffee, juicy malt, grape jam, and caramel.
Hints of orange marmalade, dark rum, and vanilla follow through. 

Medium bodied and quite sticky. A bit syrupy due to low carbonation.

Sweet malt and candi sugar lead off the pallet along with rum-soaked raisins, sugared caramel, and brown sugar. Some mild alcohol follows through on the throat. 

Finishes with faint orangy notes, juicy malt, and more raisins.

This beer has a great nose, but the carbonation is way low for the style and the pallet is overly sweet.
Bottle at Chris o’scopper,sweet hop, yeastybreasy hop nice juicy belgian hop

Bottle.  Gusher!  The cork popped out as I was untwisting the cage.  Pours a dark murky brown with a huge, thick creamy tan head.  Aroma of apple, pear, dark fruits, squash and other vegetables, and light spices.  Flavor is extremely sweet with a lot of squash, almost soda-like.  This definitely needs some age on it because it is super super sweet.  Hard to enjoy with all the sugar.

Numerous 750ml bottles.  Each bottle changes in character, in particular the ’sweetness’ variable.  First pour is dark mahogany with coca cola cherry red highlighst and a really big head.  Hard to get a grasp of all the flavor components, but there’s alot of rich, sweet mal, and dark fruits -- raisins, prunes, sweet figs, and caramel butterscotch candy.  A bit of rum creeps in.
